questions.text: Which of the following best describes Tangier disease?
questions.solution:
Tangier disease

  • It is marked by extremely low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol due to mutations in the ABCA1 gene on chromosome 9q31, which impairs cholesterol transport.
  • Defects in ABCA1 are characterized by two clinical hallmarks; enlarged lipid-laden tonsils and low serum HDL.
  • Also known as Familial alpha-lipoprotein deficiency/Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia.
  • This mutation causes a decreased level of Apo A1,where HDL is not properly formed.
  • Leads to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues such as the tonsils, liver, spleen, and corneas.
  • Clinical features : Include enlarged orange-colored tonsils, peripheral neuropathy, hepatosplenomegaly and early-onset cardiovascular disease.

 

Low VLDL levels (Option A)  are not characteristic of Tangier disease. VLDL primarily carries triglycerides, and its levels are not significantly affected in Tangier disease.

 

Low LDL levels (Option C) are not specifically affected in Tangier disease. LDL primarily carries cholesterol to tissues, and its levels can vary independently of HDL levels.

 

Low LDL receptor activity (Option D): This describes familial hypercholesterolemia, not Tangier disease. Familial hypercholesterolemia is characterized by high LDL cholesterol levels due to defective LDL receptors on cell surfaces.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with developmental delays, visual impairment, and recurrent episodes of ataxia. Laboratory tests reveal low serum levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins. A blood smear shows the presence of acanthocytes. Which of the following findings is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Elevated levels of chylomicrons in the bloodstream.
High serum levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL).

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Absence of apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins

 

Explanation:

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the inability to synthesize apolipoprotein B (Apo B), which is essential for the formation of certain lipoproteins.

Pathophysiology:

  • Caused by mutations in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene.
  • Leads to impaired assembly and secretion of lipoproteins, particularly chylomicrons and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL). (Option A and D ruled out)
  • Results in low serum levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K).

Clinical Features:

  • Fat malabsorption leads to steatorrhea (fatty stools). (Option C ruled out)
  • Deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins can cause:
    • Retinitis pigmentosa (leading to blindness).
    • Neurological deficits (e.g., ataxia, developmental delays).
  • Presence of acanthocytes (spiny red blood cells) on blood smear.

Management:

  • Dietary management to provide essential fatty acids and fat-soluble vitamins.
  • Supplementation with medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) may be beneficial.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the mechanisms of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in post-heparinized blood samples. They conduct a mixing study to differentiate between a deficiency of apolipoprotein C-II (Apo C-II) and LPL deficiency. Which of the following outcomes from the mixing study would most accurately indicate an Apo C-II deficiency?

choices.text: The addition of pooled normal plasma results in no change in LPL activity.
LPL activity normalizes after mixing with normal plasma.
A significant increase in triglyceride levels is observed after mixing.
LPL activity decreases following the addition of normal plasma.

questions.solution:
• If the LPL activity normalises after mixing, it is an Apo C II defect.
  • Post-heparinized blood samples are used because heparin in circulation competes with heparan sulfate on vessel walls, causing enzymes to detach from the vessel wall and attach to circulating heparin.
  • If LPL activity is low in post-heparinized individuals, it is either an Apo C II defect or an LPL defect.

 

Mixing study to differentiate Apo C defect from LPL defect:

  • In the patients post heparinized plasma, add an equal amount of pooled normal plasma which acts as a source of apo C II.
    • If LPL activity normalizes it is an apo C II defect and it will respond to FFP administration.
    • If LPL activity does not normalize it is an LPL defect (Option A).

 

An increase in triglyceride levels is not indicative of Apo C-II deficiency and does not relate directly to the expected outcomes of the mixing study. (Option C)

Decrease in LPL activity after mixing would suggest an error in the experiment or another underlying issue, not an Apo C-II deficiency. (Option D)

questions.text:
Match the following contributing factors with their corresponding effects on fatty liver:

 


	
		
			
			A) Choline Deficiency
			
			
			1) Increases NADH, hindering fatty acid oxidation and promoting triacylglycerol accumulation.
			
		
		
			
			B) Orotic Acid Interference
			
			
			2) Impairs VLDL secretion, resulting in triacylglycerol accumulation and a fatty liver.
			
		
		
			
			C) Vitamin E and Selenium
			
			
			3) Involved in pyrimidine synthesis. Disrupts VLDL glycosylation, hindering release.
			
		
		
			
			D) Ethanol Consumption
			
			
			4) Protect against liver damage from lipid peroxidation
questions.solution:
Fatty Liver-Contributing Factors

Choline Deficiency
  • Choline is crucial for lipid metabolism.
  • Deficiency impairs VLDL secretion, resulting in triacylglycerol accumulation and a fatty liver.

Orotic Acid Interference
  • Involved in pyrimidine synthesis
  • Disrupts VLDL glycosylation, hindering release.

Nutritional Deficiencies
  • Deficiencies in essential fatty acids, vitamins (linoleic acid, pyridoxine, pantothenic acid), and protein contribute to fatty liver.

Ethanol Consumption
  • Ethanol metabolism increases NADH, hindering fatty acid oxidation and promoting triacylglycerol accumulation.

Vitamin E and Selenium
  • Protect against liver damage from lipid peroxidation, especially in choline deficiency-induced fatty liver.

questions.text: Which among the following is a true statement on electrophoretic mobility of lipoproteins seen during serum electrophoresis?

choices.text: HDL shows the least mobility due to high lipid content.
Lipoproteins with higher protein content move slower towards the anode.
Lipoproteins with higher protein content migrate faster towards the anode
Lipoproteins identified by dye color after staining with lipid dyes, not electrophoretic mobility.

questions.solution:
The serum is applied on cellulose acetate, electric current is applied for 2 hours, the strip is dried and stained with lipid dyes, such as Oil Red O. Higher protein content will move faster towards the anode and those with less proteins have minimum mobility.

 

HDL shows the highest mobility, followed by VLDL, IDL, and LDL. (Option A ruled out)

Lipoproteins with higher protein content move faster towards the anode. (Option B ruled out)

Staining helps visualize lipoproteins, their electrophoretic mobility is crucial for identifying and classifying them. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, enlarged tonsils, and orange-colored tonsils. His lipid profile shows very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Further investigation reveals that the patient has a rare genetic condition leading to severe HDL deficiency. Given these findings, which of the following gene mutations is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A)ABCA1 gene mutation

The patient presents findings most likely points towards the diagnosis of Tangier disease.

Tangier disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ABCA1 (ATP-binding cassette, sub-family A, member 1) gene.

 

Pathophysiology: The ABCA1 protein is crucial for the efflux of cholesterol and phospholipids to apolipoprotein A-I (ApoA-I), forming HDL particles. Mutations in the ABCA1 gene impair this process, leading to a shortage of HDL and cholesterol accumulation in tissues such as the tonsils, liver, spleen, and peripheral nerves.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Greyish-Orange Tonsils: (Hallmark feature) Tonsils, become enlarged and acquire a greyish-orange hue due to the accumulation of cholesterol esters.

  • Hepatosplenomegaly: Due to cholesterol and phospholipid accumulation.
  • Peripheral Neuropathy: Multiple nerves can be individually affected due to cholesterol deposition in peripheral nerves, leading to peripheral neuropathy.

 

LDLR gene mutations(Option B) are associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, which primarily affects low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels, not HDL levels.

 

APOE gene mutation (Option C) is associated with various lipid disorders and Alzheimer's disease. While APOE influences lipid metabolism, it does not specifically cause the severe HDL deficiency.

 

PCSK9 gene mutations (Option D) are linked to familial hypercholesterolemia, affecting LDL cholesterol levels rather than HDL. These mutations result in increased LDL and cholesterol levels and are not associated with HDL deficiency.

Match the apolipoproteins with their respective functions in lipid metabolism:

			Function

			2) Apolipoprotein B-100

questions.text:
Following are the substrates of cholesterol synthesis. Arrange them in order of appearance in the cholesterol synthesis pathway.


	Mevalonate
	Squalene
	Lanosterol
	Zymosterol
	Desmosterol
questions.solution:
The substrates of cholesterol synthesis appear in the following order:

  1. Mevalonate
  2. Isopentenyl pyrophosphate (IPP)
  3. Farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP) 
  4. Squalene
  5. Lanosterol
  6. Zymosterol
  7. Desmosterol
  8. Cholesterol

So, the correct order of the listed substrates in the cholesterol synthesis pathway is:

Mevalonate → Squalene → Lanosterol → Zymosterol → Desmosterol.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of progressive kidney dysfunction and recurrent episodes of hemolytic anemia. On examination, the patient is found to have corneal opacification on slit-lamp examination. His lipid profile shows high levels of cholesterol and lipoprotein X. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) LCAT deficiency

The most likely diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is LCAT deficiency (Lecithin-Cholesterol Acyltransferase deficiency).

LCAT deficiency exists in two primary forms:

 

 

Partial LCAT Deficiency

(Fish eye disease)

Complete LCAT Deficiency (Norum’s disease)

LCAT Enzyme Activity

Partial loss, mainly affecting corneal lipid metabolism

Severe impairment or absence, leading to systemic issues

Corneal Appearance

Fish-eye appearance due to cholesterol ester accumulation

Fisheye disease: similar corneal opacification

Systemic Involvement

Less severe, primarily ocular

Severe: hemolytic anemia, CKD, early myocardial infarction, progressive End-stage renal disease

 

 

Tangier disease(Option A) is associated with very low HDL levels and characteristic features such as orange tonsils and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia (Option B) typically presents with high LDL levels, xanthomas, and early cardiovascular disease, but not hemolytic anemia or corneal opacification.

 

Niemann-Pick disease (Option D) is a lysosomal storage disorder involving neurological symptoms and organomegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary function of Very Low-Density Lipoprotein (VLDL) in the body?

choices.text: Transport of dietary cholesterol to the liver
Transport of triglycerides from the liver to peripheral tissues
Removal of cholesterol from peripheral tissues to the liver
Storage of excess cholesterol in adipose tissue

questions.solution:
VLDL is synthesized in the liver and its main role is to transport triglycerides to peripheral tissues, such as muscle and adipose tissue, where they can be used for energy or stored.

  • VLDL is rich in triglycerides and also contains cholesterol and apolipoproteins.
  • As VLDL releases triglycerides to cells, it becomes intermediate density lipoprotein(IDL) and eventually low density lipoprotein(LDL).
  • This conversion of VLDL to IDL and then to LDL is referred to as lipoprotein cascade pathway

Transport of dietary cholesterol to the liver (Option A) - This function is primarily carried out by chylomicrons, not VLDL. Chylomicrons are responsible for transporting dietary lipids, including cholesterol, from the intestines to the liver.

 

Removal of cholesterol from peripheral tissues to the liver (Option C) - This function is primarily carried out by high-density lipoprotein (HDL), not VLDL. HDL is involved in reverse cholesterol transport, carrying cholesterol away from the tissues and back to the liver for excretion.

 

Storage of excess cholesterol in adipose tissue (Option D) - This is not a function of VLDL. Excess cholesterol can be stored in various tissues, but VLDL primarily transports triglycerides, while LDL and other mechanisms are involved in cholesterol storage and transport.

questions.text:
The lipid profile of 55 Y/O female is given below:


	
		
			
			Triglycerides
			
			
			150 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Total cholesterol
			
			
			350 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			HDL
			
			
			90 mg/dL
			
		
	


Calculate LDL level of this patient.
questions.solution:
LDL of the patient can be calculated using

 

Friedwald’s equation:

Total cholesterol = HDL+LDL+TG/5 mg/dL

Substituting the values,

350 = 90+LDL+150/5

LDL = 350-90-30

= 230 mg/dL

 

Friedwald’s equation is accurate when triglycerides levels are below 400 mg/dL.

 

Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which enzyme facilitates the conversion of discoidal HDL into spheroidal HDL in HDL metabolism?
questions.solution:
Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of discoidal HDL (aka Nascent HDL- amphipathic) into spheroidal HDL (aka Mature HDL- hydrophobic). It catalyzes the transfer of an acyl group from lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) to cholesterol, forming cholesteryl esters.

 

HDL Metabolism

  • HDL Formation: Formed in the liver and intestines as nascent, discoidal particles rich in apolipoprotein A-I (apoA-I).
  • Cholesterol Efflux: ABCA1 Transporter, transfers free cholesterol and phospholipids to nascent HDL. ABCG1 and SR-BI Transporters facilitate cholesterol efflux to HDL.
  • Maturation of HDL: Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) converts discoidal HDL into spherical HDL by forming cholesterol esters that move to the core of HDL particles.
  • HDL Remodeling: Phospholipid transfer protein (PLTP) and cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) modify HDL size and composition by transferring lipids between lipoproteins.
  • Selective Uptake and HDL Recycling: Scavenger Receptor Class B Type I (SR-BI) facilitates selective uptake of cholesterol esters from HDL into hepatocytes. CETP transfers cholesteryl esters from HDL to VLDL and LDL for liver uptake.
  • Excretion:The liver converts cholesterol into bile acids or secretes it into bile for excretion via intestines.

 

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) (Option A) is an enzyme that hydrolyzes triglycerides in lipoproteins into free fatty acids and glycerol.

 

Hepatic lipase (Option C) primarily hydrolyzes triglycerides and phospholipids in intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL) and low-density lipoproteins (LDL).

 

Cholesteryl ester transfer protein (Option D) (CETP), facilitates the transfer of cholesteryl esters and triglycerides between lipoproteins.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding bile acid synthesis regulation?


	7α-hydroxylation is the step which is suppressed
	Cholic acid suppresses the synthesis
	Farnesoid X receptor is activated
	Transcription of the CYP7A1 gene is suppressed
questions.solution:
Chenodeoxycholic acid is the most potent bile acid which suppresses bile acid production, not cholic acid

 

Regulation of bile acid synthesis:

Excess of chenodeoxycholic acid  →  Farnesoid X receptor (FXR) activation  →  Suppresses transcription of the CYP7A1 gene  →  7-alpha-hydroxylase enzyme production suppressed  →  7α-hydroxylation of cholesterol (rate-limiting step) is suppressed  →  Bile acid production is suppressed

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the fate of cholesterol?


	Chenodeoxycholic acid and cholic acid are the primary bile acids
	Glycine-taurine conjugation happens in liver peroxisomes
	Intestinal bacteria produce secondary bile acids
questions.solution:
• Chenodeoxycholic acid and cholic acid are the primary bile acids.
  • Deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid are secondary bile acids.
  • Primary bile acids are conjugated in liver peroxisomes. They are converted into glycine or taurine conjugates.
  • Intestinal bacteria deconjugate and de-hydroxylase the glycine-taurine conjugates to form secondary bile acids.

Note: The anions of bile acids and their glycine or taurine conjugates are referred to as bile salts. In the alkaline environment of bile, they are expected to exist in this form.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyzes the principal regulatory step of cholesterol synthesis?
questions.solution:
• The principal regulatory step in the cholesterol synthesis pathway: HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate, catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase
  • Site- cytoplasm and smooth endoplasmic reticulum

 

Regulation of HMG-CoA reductase:

Category

Regulation Method

Mechanism

Allosteric Modification

Statins (e.g., Lovastatin)

Competitive inhibition of HMG CoA reductase

Covalent Modification

AMP-activated Kinase

Phosphorylates HMG CoA reductase, inactivating it

Protein Phosphatase 1

Dephosphorylates HMG CoA reductase, activating it

Induction or Repression

Sufficient Cholesterol

Suppresses transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene

Low Dietary Cholesterol

Increases transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene

Insulin and Thyroxine

Increase the activity of HMG CoA reductase (induction)

Cortisol and Glucagon

Decrease the activity of HMG CoA reductase (repression)

 

HMG CoA synthase (Option A) catalyzes the formation of HMG-CoA from acetyl-CoA and acetoacetyl-CoA, which is an upstream step in the cholesterol synthesis pathway but not the rate-limiting step.

- HMG CoA Synthase is also a part of ketone body synthesis pathway (mitochondrial)

- Cholesterol pathway enzyme is cytoplasmic

 

Cytosolic thiolase (Option C) is involved in an upstream step of cholesterol synthesis by converting two molecules of acetyl-CoA into acetoacetyl-CoA, not directly involved in the regulatory step.

 

Squalene epoxidase (Option D) catalyzes the conversion of squalene to squalene-2,3-epoxide, a downstream step in the cholesterol synthesis pathway, but it is not a regulatory step.
